Watch it! It is a good movie. Yes it's about cancer but the whole story is 
about how life can still be good and have meaning and beautiful and worth 
it, even if it's not a long life. It's about love and friendship in 
difficult times. And it's a positive view on life, even with a disease. I 
lost a good friend of mine when we were 17 because of cancer and untill the 
very end, she was positive and didn't let the disease stop her from living 
her live, even though it was a different and shorter one. In my opinion, 
this movie has that same message. So I would encourage you to watch it, if 
you want to.

comments.text:
+El000n I really haven't spent a lot of time on this book.  At least not as 
much as I want to.  Just enough time to read, think about, and somewhat 
discuss it.  I relate to it more than anything.  Quite closely actually.  

I don't know why you think that something has to be original to be good. 
 Originality has nothing to do with a story's quality.  A classic example 
is the story of Hamlet and The Lion King.  Would you argue that The Lion 
King is crap because it's pretty much the story of Hamlet?  Of course not.  

Regardless, I think TFiOS is quite original.  Which book is TFiOS based off 
of?  I asked Kira to share her opinion on why this book is "nothing new" 
and why it's just another love story.  Maybe you could answer this question 
for me as well?  Your criticisms against this book so far have no support 
and I would just like to understand your reasoning as to why you think it's 
nothing special.
comments.author: Warheroguy

comments.author: El000n

comments.text:
It's a love story, but that's not all it is. It's not like the Notebook 
where EVERY 10 seconds, it's making out. The "Love" part takes a good while 
to come to play which makes it very realistic. The story is funny, 
charming, and it really can relate to everyone. It's just over time, these 
two characters become so in sync with one another that they fall in love.
comments.author: Alysa Spivak

comments.text:
+I'mNot Kira Have you read the book?  I find it so hard to believe that 
people who have actually experienced the words in the story can come to 
this conclusion.  Yes, it's a love story.  But why is that bad?  Are all 
love stories instantly bad and unoriginal now?  The only similarity to your 
stereotypical romance novel is that there are two people in love.  Then 
things change.  It's not about two teens from high school falling in love. 
 That's even somewhat made fun of in the story.  It's not that story of one 
sick person falling in love with a healthy person and then said healthy 
person gaining a new outlook on life.  It's not just about the lovers. 
 It's their families.  It's their friends.  It's about them and how they 
effect the world and everyone around them.  It's about how someone can 
experience a FULL life even if it's cut short.  It's about how your views 
don't have to match to love someone.  I don't know how you can say it's 
"nothing new" unless your mind is too dull to comprehend the important 
messages told throughout the story.  

Your opinion is not unique.  Many others share it.  Most of those people, 
like Meowbunbun, say these things just because they can.  They don't know 
anything about the book, but there's two people in love so it's 
automatically a Twilight copy.  Are you one of those people?  If not, 
please share in detail what you mean by "nothing new."  I would really like 
to know.
comments.author: Warheroguy

comments.text: Yeah I agree. ANOTHER tragic love story. Nothing new.

airplane (don't know why I bothered to add that part), and when I read the 
chapter where he died, it just wasn't.. right. It would've made me tear up 
at the least, but it didn't. It was so sudden that I was just surprised. 
Not much drama or sorrow that was put into that part, and I was a little 
disappointed. Same with the other parts of the book. I just thought the 
narrator would be more.. hm. special. coming from a book, you'd expect 
Green to write about the specialties of this child with cancer and not 
point out the stereotypes and obvious "teenage attitude". They're both 
brilliant and beautiful in their own ways, but the puzzle pieces just 
weren't right. I'd love to see the movie, though.

comments.author: Karina Schuler

comments.text:
+Demi Lovatic Gus is a cliche fantasy - the wise beyond his years old soul 
who is prone to waxing philosophic on the trivialities yet grandeur of 
everyday life; the poetic - that you can find in pretty much any romance 
centric story targeted and teen girls. He is sooooo painfully generic in 
his pretension. He nor Hazel are in any way likeable.

I have read YA novels with cliche, generic characters that I still 
loved/liked anyway; Maxon from The Selection for example (I'm still 
surprised I actually like those books, seriously, not my thing. Anyways!) 
But I just can't with Gus, or Hazel. I just roll my eyes.

I mean yea these kids have cancer and yea I suppose their personalities are 
likely a side effect of their conditions and I can sympathise, I can 
understand where they're coming from...but I still don't like them.

I saw somewhere, maybe this video actually, that Green wanted to present 
sick-kid characters in a way that was counter to how they usually are...he 
even has his characters harp on and on about the stereotype...and he does 
the exact same thing he set out NOT to do.

Maybe its a satire and that is being lost on me.

I read reviews on Good Reads and saw that *******SPOILER ALERT******* Gus 
dies ******SPOILER ALERT*******. Usually I'd be upset that I found out a 
character died before I reached the end - not finished it yet - but I 
really didn't care.

comments.text:
+Inkimetromic Of course I can, thank you for asking.

I get much hate because of my dislike of The Fault in our Stars.  People 
tell me that I'm not supporting cancer patients --- I do.  If anything, 
most of my dislike towards this book is because of how poorly it represents 
people with cancer.  Maybe not even poor representation so much as cancer 
was shoved in the backseat for poorly-chemistrated romance to take the 
front stage.

And before anyone starts telling me that I've never had cancer and have no 
right to judge, let me just say that I've had a close aunt have cancer and 
it's just as bad, watching someone in pain 24 hours a day and feeling 
absolutely useless that you can't do anything.  

I wasn't there to hold her hand when she died.

Anyway, back to TFIOS.  Like I said, cancer took a backseat and was 
basically just used as fuel for the romance.  The characters were 
inconsistent --- I couldn't really get a hold of Hazel's personality enough 
to get the vibe of cancer sympathy that I honestly did want to get.

Augustus, or Gus, is one of the most unrealistic characters I've read in a 
modern-setting novel thus far.  The things he says is completely 
unrealistic --- for example, on page 153, word for word: "I'm in love with 
you, and I'm not in the business of denying myself the simple pleasure of 
saying true things.  I'm in love with you, and I know that love is just a 
shout into the void, and that oblivion is inevitable, and that we're all 
doomed and that there will come a day when all our labor has been returned 
to dust, and I know the sun will swallow the only earth we'll ever have, 
and I'm in love with you."

Seriously?  No.  Sometimes they act like hormonal teenagers and sometimes 
like million-year-old sages, and it's too much for me to read a book when I 
don't know who the character actually is.  

I didn't get the plot much either nor most of the characters.  Some, I 
felt, were thrown in just because they had to.  What was the point of the 
book in the first place?  I picked it up, read it, and gained practically 
nothing.

comments.text:
+Froggie06855 Entertainment Do you want reasons?  I can give you reasons.

The romance was poorly chemist rated, as if the characters were in love 
simply because the author decided on it.

The characters' personalities weren't very consistent either, in my 
opinion.  Maybe it was just me, but I thought that there were too many 
changes and shifts in how they acted.

And maybe it's just me, but I don't like novels in which it's centered 
purely around romance.  There are exceptions, of course, which I thought 
The Fault In Our Stars would be, but it didn't turn out to be.

Perhaps it actually is a good book --- maybe I'm just too picky.  

Ah, the final sentences was to provide the basis in case a fan actually 
wanted to find out my reasons.  In that case, I would've given them reasons 
like I gave you.  My reasons might be invalid, but they're reasons, at the 
very least.

Sure, I want attention.  I'm not going to deny that.  It's in my nature --- 
I'm a very despicable person, if that wasn't already obvious.  So, in case 
I gave you the wrong idea, just know that, yes, my comment was orchestrated 
to get me attention.

comments.text:
to be honest the beauty of this book is the simplicity of it I think. I 
mean I know that it can't be 100% realistic because nothing is, and people 
write and read books to sometimes escape from reality you know? even if 
there is a bit of reality in their. I personally love this book because 
it's just such a lovely story and a lot of people can relate to it. I don't 
mean a lot of people can relate to it because they may have had an illness 
or known people that have, even though these people could relate, 
obviously. People can also relate even if they're going through hard times 
personally or have struggles in their life but may not be as drastic as a 
physical terminal illness but still find the struggles just as hard. We do 
not live in a perfect world and people will judge you and be mean an and 
things won't go right and people who have illnesses and things like that 
obviously it's very hard for them. But the beauty about this book is that 
life is life. No matter what you're going through you're still here. Even 
if it isn't for long, life is for everyone and it can be beautiful.

comments.text:
+Pierce The Sirens From an amateurs writer's perspective, making the 
"realistic character" is endlessly boring to write and read. Would a book 
about an ordinary teenage girl, doing tests and working a part time job, 
dotted and splashed with all of the like's and literally's that come in the 
ordinary teenage conversations be interesting? Hell no! It's a book rather 
than a biography. The way he strings together characters and adds those 
suck punch lines that obviously would never happen realistically is his 
artwork. He's a fairly unique writer when it comes to his characters and 
impeccable dialogue. You either embrace it, respect it or avoid wasting 
your time with his books all together!

+tad winslo
John Green used that line as the title because with the line in 
Shakespeare's Julius Caesar was used as an explanation that we are at fault 
for our actions. That any consequences are not because of the stars or 
gods, but rather we are responsible for our state of being. But in the 
Fault in our Stars, the characters' lives are the antithesis of that line. 
Their cancer is not any result of their actions. Rather, they were simply 
part of them through no fault of their own. So in that sense, it is a fault 
in their stars. It is just the way they were.

comments.author: vesper selene

comments.text:
No, it's not real, but there are real people all around the world whose 
story it COULD be. That's why stories are important - they open ideas up to 
us and make us feel things and connect to notions that we may never 
experience first-hand for ourselves. They represent people we may never 
meet and positions we may never find ourselves in. Just because a story 
isn't true doesn't mean it's not relevant or not applicable to real life, 
and if a story can spark an emotional reaction as strong as this one has 
for a lot of the people who've read/seen it, then that's a great success on 
the storyteller's part in connecting their audience to the subject in 
question.

comments.text:
+DaddysPrincess148 It's a story about two people meeting and falling in 
love, but being afraid to let that love grow because one of them is sure to 
die soon due to cancer. It has a lot of religious undertones (Waters and 
Grave overcoming their struggles to find love). They decide to be together 
despite what they know will happen. They change each other for the better; 
and are even able to accept it when the other dies and remain the better 
person they were made into.


Really the only  differences are that the Characters in A Walk To Remember 
are more fleshed out and diverse (Gus and Hazel aren't really much 
different), The Fault In Our Stars tries to throw in what it thinks is a 
twist (Oh, how unpredictable. The cancer-ridden guy who teaches a girl that 
it's okay to love someone you know will die; dies. How could I ever have 
expected that).

read a book like that, but it could just be a sign that you're more mature 
than most kids your age. That's how I am, so you're getting a first-hand 
opinion. Ask yourself: Do not complain about things most kids would? Do 
just do what needs to be done in terms of work? Do treat others with 
respect, even those you don't like? If you answered yes to all of those, 
high school might be rough for you, but the rest of your life will turn out 
so much better due to your early maturity.

before, but not one like this.

are just bigger than others.

comments.text:
I usually can tell by the preview if a movie is going to be. Also, I never 
said it was a chick flick or that there was such a thing. It's not 
educating for people who already know this stuff. I've been through the 
system since I was a child, and have gone through many support groups 
because of the abuse I went through from my family. This movie doesn't look 
interesting at all. There's alot of really good 'realistic' movies. I saw 
Ultimate Life in the theater. It's a sequel to Ultimate Gift, but way 
better. Another good movie made by a dancer is - Mouth to Mouth. There's 
also a older book that was made into a movie called Girl Interrupted which 
is excellent. And a movie called Pumpkin (2002) which is extremely good.

captions.text: I believe we have a choice in this world.
Oh my god! It's The Fault in Our Stars!
I read this book.

I'm reading this book right now! 
I don't want spoilers.

Where nothing is too messed up that
can't be fixed with a Peter Gabriel song.
I'm gonna start crying.

I like that version as much 
as the next girl does.
So it's like Twilight?
It's just not the truth.
This is the truth.
Hey! Make some friends.

This is gonna be good, 
I can already tell.
I can already tell.
I'm Augustus Waters--

This is the only love story
I want to watch.

Maybe you'd like to share 
some of your fears with the group.

-Oblivion.
-Why are you guys doing this to me?

-What's your full name? 
-Hazel Grace Lancaster.

-Why're you staring at me? 
-'Cause you're beautiful.
Stalker.

-So, what's your story? 
-I was diagnosed when I was 13--

-No, your real story?
-(laughter)

You know, Augustus talks
about you all the time.

-We're just friends.
-Awww!

-I hope you realize--
-Friend zoned!

The movie makes it seem 
like such a chick flick!
Gus, I'm a grenade.
One day I'm gonna blow up...

and I'm gonna obliterate 
everything in my wake.

I'll have to bring a box of tissues
with me to this movie.

You don't get to choose 
if you get hurt in this world,
but you do have a say in who hurts you.
I am in love with you, Hazel Grace.
That's a good guy right there.
She seems older than I pictured.

Oblivion is inevitable 
and I am in love with you.

-Are you angry?
-So angry.

-You need to break something.
-Oh!

-(cheering)
-A car!

You gave me a forever
within the numbered days,

and I can't tell you how they
cry out for a little infinity.

-It's a good life, Hazel Grace.
-Okay?

-Okay.
-Okay.
Oh my god!

I love this book.
I can't wait until the movie comes out.
Oh, it's so good!
I can't stand how much I love that story.

I'm so excited for this movie!
You don't even understand!

(Finebros) So, have you heard 
of The Fault in Our Stars

-before we showed you this?
-No.
I have not.
It's a book!

Oh my god!
Who hasn't heard
of A Fault in Our Stars?

Everyone's talking about it.
All my friends are obsessed with it.

-Um...
-(Finebros laughing) No way!

This Fault in Our Stars
that I just decided
I needed to reread before the movie?

-(Finebros) Have you read the book?
-No!
No, I didn't hear about it at all.
Is this a big thing right now?
I have not read the book yet!

My friends have been telling me about it
and handing me the book

almost everyday at school.
"Jeordy, you need to read the book!"
I'm reading it right now.
I loved the book.
There you go! (laughs)

(Finebros) So back to the trailer,
how did it make you feel?
It made me feel nice!
It was kind of warm and fuzzy.

It kind of made me feel 
a little bit like a girl.

I didn't really picture it 
that girly in my mind.

I wanted to cry, but then they 
would show something cute...
and then I was happy!

I've had a friend 
who's read the book six times.

She's like, "They're gonna ruin it.
It's gonna be awful!"
I want to see it.

(Finebros) The book and the movie is
about a teenage girl who has cancer,

who is forced to go to a cancer 
support group by her mom to make friends.

What are your thoughts about someone 
deciding to make a story revolving

around something like
a young person having cancer?

I mean, it definitely gives 
a new perspective
to how we all look at the world.

It just makes me so happy
because I don't think

a movie like this could've 
happened ten years ago.

I think it's an innovative idea
in that the hero
isn't a great, healthy, fantastic person.

I've seen stories like that before, 
but I understand the feeling

'cause being attached to Game of Thrones,
seeing people die, that's heart wrenching.

It's heavy, but I think that we
all need to be aware of it.

Being somebody who is their age, it 
just makes me thankful and it makes me

step back and be like, "Okay. I need
to realize the good things that I have."

(Finebros) Do you know who
the author of the book is?
No.
Not at all.
John Green?
John Green.

I watch his YouTube videos and he
seems like an awesome person.

(Finebros) What do you
know about John Green?
He wrote The Fault in Our Stars?

Him and his brother
are the Vlog Brothers...
didn't they start Vidcon?
Vlog Brothers, Vidcon...
That History Show...
and That New Art Show?
I am a nerd fighter!

(Finebros) So beyond being a best selling 
author of multiple books,

-he also is a big YouTube star.
-What?!

(Finebros) John also is behind 
some education channels on YouTube,

-like Crash Force.
-Wow!

They're really smart dudes, yep.
Wow! It's that guy!
I would never expect that.

I just picture some old guy
writing a book at home,

like "Heh heh! I'm targeting 
all the teenagers!"

(Finebros) He decided to make it 
about young people who are sick

because he feels that we 
have a habit of imagining

the sick and dying 
to be different than we are,

that even in a short life, 
you can live a full life.

-What do you think about that sentiment?
-I think that's beautiful
'cause it really is true.

If that was his goal, 
he definitely achieved it.

We do think of sick people 
as different and "Other",
when really, we're all human.

Just because somebody's sick 
doesn't mean that they're different.

They can't control that they got sick.
They're just a normal person.

People think of the sick as,
"Oh, you're so sick.

You can't do this. We'll try and take
care of you, make you happy."

But all they want to do is be normal, 
be able to do the things
that other people can do.
I certainly hope that's right.
My brother died when he was 25.

We were expecting at the funeral
for maybe 100 people to show up--
over a thousand people showed up.

So I really do hope that 
a short life can be a whole life.

(Finebros) Why is this book, 
specifically, so popular

-and mean so much to your generation? 
-One: it's a love story.

It shows a different side
of the teenage life.

Even if you're not sick, 
you still feel like an outcast.

I thought that's how she feels, 
'cause she has to carry that around.

Everybody's staring at her and I feel
like today's youth feel like that too.

They feel like other people 
always judge them.

Teenagers or young people, we 
have this invincible complex

or invincibility complex. 
We don't think about death.

We don't realize that there 
are a lot of young people out there,

just like us, who die from disasters, 
who die from sickness.

Reading about somebody that has 
a dramatic situation going on their life,

and how they make it normal 
and how they're accepted,
it kind of makes us feel better.

(Finebros) And if John Green 
ended up watching this,

-what would you want to say to him? 
-I'm still not reading your book.
I'm gonna read your book.
I love your books!

Thank you, for I am sure speaking
for lots of my generation.

I don't...I don't know! 
I would be really shy!

(Finebros) The last thing we're 
going to be doing in this episode,

we're gonna show you one more thing.
You can tell him yourself, Brianna.

-Ooh!
-Hi!
Hi!

-Hi!
-(squealing) Oh my god!

-What?! Hi, John Green! 
-How's it going?
I'm going--it's going a lot better now!

-Is this real?
-(Finebros) It's him!

-I am not some old geezer.
-(laughter) Wait, has he been listening
this whole time?

Thanks for reading the book,
even though you don't know

-who I am on the internet.
-(nervous laughter) Sorry.

-You know what's really crazy?
-What?

-I had this in my bag.
-Are you serious?

Yeah! Do you think that you 
can virtually sign it somehow?
Yeah, ready? Hold on!

I heard that your friend is worried 
that it's gonna screw up the book.

I saw the movie and I'll tell you, 
I walked out of the movie--

there are, of course, very sad parts--
but I walked out of the movie so happy!

I mean, partly because I 
was relieved that I liked it

and that I think they did
a good, faithful adaptation.

-I liked it--
-But if you liked it, then...
that's all that matters!

-I'm still not reading your book.
-(laughs)

-What do I have to do?!
-Nothing, I'm just not gonna read your book.
I'm not a reader.

-What if I send you a free copy? 
-I still wouldn't read it.

-I'd probably give it to my mom.
-(laughter)

I'm going to devote myself,
over the next several decades,

to getting you to read--it doesn't 
even have to be one of my books--

but getting you
to read books for pleasure.
Okay, good luck with that.

I like writing and art stuff 
and I think that yours is brilliant.
Thank you!

Don't let the world tell 
you that those are not

realistic career aspirations
or get you down.

There's lots of good writing 
and art stuff jobs out there.

Thank you so much for telling 
a story that's so different

and that relates to so many of us
about making us feel normal

in our own situations, like
no matter what's going on.

Oh, that's so nice. 
That really means a lot to me.

-Are you gonna see the movie now?
